formalText: His wife was going to commit suicide and she was stopped before it happened. He feels there is no difference between having a plan and doing the plan.
He feels he cannot stop thinking about Tanya and he feels concern about her leading him to talk about her a lot in his sessions.
Additionally he feels if he can solve something less important, little problems in his life, then it will be easier fix Tanya.
He thinks that it his progress with Tanya isn't that helpful because it always drifts into her depression that leads to a lot of unanswerable questions.
He has a hard time trying to understand where her suicidally came, he feels she could have just walked away from what was making her sad.
Tanya expects him to be a partner to her
but he has a hard time trusting her like a partner. He thinks he loves her but often he just feels negative emotions, pain and anger.
He thinks she broke the expectations and agreement that comes along with marriage, that it is a partnership that they had a life plan together.
He  feels like he is Tanya's caretaker, cleaning the house and taking care of her for the past 6 months.
The actions that she took to hurt herself also hurt him.
If he does something that makes him feel better but hurts her, he feels like he is deliberately trying to hurt her.
He thinks if Tanya is still in a lot of pain then he should be nicer to her but he is angry that it is hard being nice to her when he is upset.
They are going to look into couples therapist.
This will allow them to fix their violation of trust.
He has a shared sense of the experience, but he needs to make sense of it for himself because it's his  experience with Tanya as his wife and his life.
Tanya has a lot of these journals about when she got depressed or when she was hospitalized, and she shares them with him.
